articleContent.title: Chord: Dominant 7b5 in A (Shape: C)
articleContent.content:
# Dominant 7b5 Chord in A (Shape: C)

The Dominant 7b5 chord, also known as the half-diminished 7 chord, is a four-note chord comprising a root note, a major third, a diminished fifth, and a minor seventh. In the key of A, when using the C shape, the notes would be C (root), E (major third), Gb (diminished fifth), and Bb (minor seventh).

## Notes and Intervals
- Root: C
- Major third: E
- Diminished fifth: Gb
- Minor seventh: Bb

## Musical Flavor
The Dominant 7b5 chord has a tense and dissonant sound due to the combination of the diminished fifth and minor seventh intervals. It is commonly used in jazz and fusion genres to add color and tension to progressions. This chord has a unique and sophisticated flavor that can create a sense of mystery or suspense in music.

## Songs
- "Blue Bossa" by Kenny Dorham
- "Autumn Leaves" by Joseph Kosma
- "So What" by Miles Davis
